method.name: GAR

reference.ref: J. Mata, J.L. Alvarez, and J.C. Riquelme. Discovering numeric association rules via evolutionary algorithm. In G.J.E. Rawlin, editor, Pacific-Asia Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (PAKDD), volume 2336 of Lecture Notes in Computer Science, pages 40–51. Springer, Heidelberg (2001).
J. Mata, J.L. Alvarez, and J.C. Riquelme. An evolutionary algorithm to discover numeric association rules. In ACM Symposium on Applied Computing, pages 590–594, Madrid, Spain (2002).

generalDescription.type: Association Rules Mining by means of Genetic Algorithms
generalDescription.objective: GAR (Genetic Association Rules) discovers frequent itemsets of a variable size by spanning as much as possible the domain intervals of all the numerical attributes without the necessity of an a priori discretization.
generalDescription.howWork: GAR evaluates the fitness of the chromosomes by rewarding frequent itemsets that have a high support as well as a high number of attributes. Moreover, it punishes frequent itemsets which have already covered a record in the database and whose intervals are too large. By following the Iterative Rule Learning (IRL) approach, it iterates until a desired number of frequent itemsets are obtained at the end of a main loop. First, an initial population is generated by randomly creating chromosomes. Then, during an internal loop, it calculates the fitness of each individual and carries out the processes of selection, crossover and mutation to complete the next population until a given number of generations is reached. At the end of this loop, the individual with the best fitness is chosen and it will correspond with one of the frequent itemsets that the algorithm returns. Moreover, records covered by the best individual are penalized in order to provoke diversity before starting over the internal loop.

parameterSpec.param: Number of Itemsets: the number of frequent itemsets to discover.
Number of Generations: the maximum number of generations to accomplish.
Population Size: the population size to handle after each generation.
Probability of Selection: the probability of selection.
Probability of Crossover: the probability of crossover.
Probability of Mutation: the probability of mutation.
Importance of Number of Records Already Covered: the factor for tuning the importance of the number of records already covered.
Importance of Intervals Amplitude: the factor for tuning the importance of the intervals amplitude.
Importance of Number of Involved Attributes: the factor for tuning the importance of the number of involved attributes.
Amplitude Factor: the amplitude factor related to each attribute of the database.
Minimum Support: the minimum support to be fullfilled by the mined association rules.
Minimum Confidence: the minimum confidence to be fullfilled by the mined association rules.

method.example:
Problem type: Association Rules Method: GAR Dataset: weather Parameters: default values (
seed = 1286082570 )

"results/Asso-GAR.weather/result0s0.tra"
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rules> <rule id="0"> <antecedents> <attribute name="humidity" value="normal"/> <attribute name="windy" value="false"/> </antecedents> <consequents> <attribute name="play" value="yes"/> </consequents> </rule> </rules>
"results/Asso-GAR.weather/result0s0.tst"
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <values> <rule id="0" rule_support="0.2857142857142857" antecedent_support="0.2857142857142857" confidence="1.0"/> </values>
